heading: french stage second net strike
subheading: for the second time in two months, french internet users boycott france télécom to protest high fees. politicians hop on the bandwagon. heather mccabe reports from paris.
author: heather mccabe
text: paris -- french internet users, miffed at seeing their phone bills creep up every minute they stay online, held their second strike in two months to dramatize their unhappiness with france télécom. the strikers staged a boycott on sunday, refusing to connect to the net for 24 hours. they hoped that a sudden drop in internet traffic, and revenue, would get the company's attention.in france, as in much of europe, local calls are charged by the minute in addition to a monthly service fee. to connect to the internet by modem in france, a user pays us$3 an hour during the day and $1 an hour at night. france télécom, the country's largest phone company, has a virtual monopoly on local calls.groups protesting these rates would like to see the tariffs reduced to the equivalent of 12 cents an hour or $34.87 a month for an unlimited connection. among their other demands are development of adsl, competition among the phone companies, and net access through the electricity network.there's more at stake than just smaller phone bills. france, and much of europe, lags behind the united states in cultivating net and telecom companies, partly because fewer people can afford to spend time online. so far, the environment isn't friendly to indigenous, would-be amazon.coms.for this strike, organizers estimate they had about the same impact as the first strike, which took place 13 december. the association of malcontent internauts said about 350,000 people participated. worldnet, a french isp backing the strike, reported a 45 percent decrease in connections and 50 percent less activity in the newsgroups."the first boycott was a huge success in our eyes, thanks to the repercussion of the media," said benoit tabaka, a member of malcontent internauts. "even so, france télécom and other isps said that the decrease was due to holiday shopping and good weather. yesterday, the stores were closed, it was cold, so these arguments do not justify this new decrease."for its part, france télécom has yet to announce lower phone rates, although it has hinted at charging a monthly fee for a certain number of hours. as of midday monday, the company had not commented on the strike.the case is different, however, for the french government. the president of the national assembly, laurent fabius, strongly supports a reduction in tariffs. and lionel jospin recently made a speech advocating universal net access.the strike brought out a bit of french pride in some net users."it's time to wake up," said luc jourdain, who on the day of the boycott decided to create kruch france télécom, a more militant group to fight against france télécom. "the future of our country depends on this. imagine france lagging behind in telecommunications. a defeat!"
